questions.text:
Below are the steps for conducting a systematic review. Select the option that states the correct order of the steps.


	Data extraction
	Data synthesis
	Selecting the studies
	Defining the review question and eligibility criteria
	Searching for the studies
	Result Interpretation
questions.solution:
Systematic review is a method used in literature where multiple studies, both published and unpublished, are collected and rigorously analysed (except quantitative analysis)

The steps followed in a systematic review are:

 

Systematic Review Process

A systematic review follows a rigorous, step-by-step methodology to collect and analyze evidence from multiple studies. This ensures transparency, reduces bias, and helps generate strong conclusions for clinical and public health decision-making.

Step

Paraphrased Description

1. Formulating the Research Question

Start by framing a specific, well-defined question using models like PICO (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome). This step directs all following activities.

2. Developing a Protocol

Create a comprehensive plan that includes aims, eligibility criteria, and methods for searching, screening, and synthesizing studies. Register the protocol in databases like PROSPERO.

3. Identifying Studies

Perform an extensive literature search across various sources with no language barriers. Use predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria.

4. Selecting Relevant Studies

Screen titles, abstracts, and full texts using explicit criteria. Involve multiple reviewers and resolve disagreements through discussion or a third-party reviewer.

5. Assessing Quality

Evaluate the methodological strength of included studies using standard checklists to gauge bias and relevance for synthesis.

6. Data Extraction and Summarization

Use uniform tools to extract key data from studies. Summarize findings using descriptive tables and figures.

7. Synthesizing the Evidence

Combine data either qualitatively or quantitatively (meta-analysis), depending on the heterogeneity of studies. Subgroup analysis may be applied.

8. Interpreting and Reporting

Discuss the strength, limitations, and implications of the findings. Provide recommendations and suggestions for future research directions.

 

  • Enhances credibility and reproducibility of results.
     
  • Reduces selection and publication bias.
     
  • Supports evidence-based practice and policy development.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes meta-analysis?

choices.text: Quantitative analysis of the result derived from a single study
Conducting time-specific research and analysing the same
Analysis of results derived from multiple studies
Conducting population-specific research and analysing the same

questions.solution:
• Meta-analysis is simply an analysis of results derived from multiple studies.
  • It quantitatively and qualitatively analyses the results from various studies to reach a common conclusion. It differs from a systematic review in that the latter can be used to analyse the outcome of only a single study.
  • Meta-analysis takes the upper hand because the final outcome will always be reliable if multiple studies on the same topic are being analysed rather than a single study.

questions.text: All of the following are true about funnel plot except?

choices.text: It is used in both systematic review and meta-analysis
Unbiased results of large-scale studies will be near the average
A triangular distribution of results indicates the absence of heterogeneity
A positive file drawer means many good outcomes of research were unpublished

questions.solution:
A positive file drawer means some of the research's bad outcomes were unpublished.

A funnel plot is drawn while conducting both a systematic review and meta-analysis (Option A) to determine whether there is any heterogeneity or publication bias.

Graph description:

  • X-axis: Study's precision.
  • The central vertical line shows the average, and the negative and positive outcomes of the studies are on the left and right sides of the average line, respectively.
  • Y-axis: Standard errors in descending order from bottom to top.

Unbiased large-scale studies generally have fewer errors (considering the huge sample population) provided there is no bias; hence, these studies will be plotted at the top close to the average line (Option B).

Unbiased smaller studies are generally more prone to errors and thus plotted at the bottom and distributed on both sides away from the average line. If there is no publication bias or heterogeneity (Option C), this gives a triangular/inverted funnel-shaped plot.

File drawer effect: This refers to a graph pattern in which all the results are plotted predominantly on either side of the average line, signifying publication bias (meaning some parts of the results never went beyond the researcher’s file drawer).

 

Positive file drawer effect

Negative file drawer effect

Most of the bad research outcomes are not published, leading to the clubbing of results to the right of the average line.

Most good research outcomes are not published, leading to the clubbing of results to the left of the average line.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the use of a blobbogram?

choices.text: Association of multiple risk factors with the same disease
Association of one risk factor with selected diseases
Association of one risk factor for a disease with another
Association of multiple risk factors with selected diseases

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (A) Association of multiple risk factors with the same disease

A blobbogram/forest plot is used in a meta-analysis to find out the association between multiple risk factors related to the same disease.

Example: Consider the blobbogram given below, which depicts 5 different studies about the association of 5 different risk factors for breast cancer.

Particulars in a Blobbogram:

OR (Odd’s ratio)

An OR of 1 means no association; <1 means the factor considered is not risky / a protective factor ; >1 means the factor considered is risky.

Solid vertical line

Corresponds to the Odd’s ratio of no effect.

Diamond

A summary measure signifies the overall association of all the risk factors with the disease.

Broken vertical line

Corresponds to the summary measure.

Black shapes

This signifies the sample population's size is proportionate to the shape's size.

Horizontal lines

Confidence intervals (where 95% of the results fall) of each study.

 

Interpretation:

  • If the confidence interval of a study crosses 1, the risk factor association cannot be taken as conclusive, i.e., insignificant (Smith 1991, Jones 1993, Smith 1999).
  • The more the confidence interval moves away from either side of 1, the stronger the association between the factors (risk/protective) and the disease (Ng 2004, Chu 2009—greater risk association as the confidence intervals lie to the right of 1).

questions.text: Which is not a reporting format used in systematic review and meta-analysis?

choices.text: PRISMA
COCHRANE
QUOROM
CONSORT

questions.solution:
CONSORT (Consolidated Standard of Reporting Trials) is a format specifically designed to report the results of individual randomised controlled trials (and not that of a meta-analysis).

Reporting the result of a systematic review or a meta-analysis involves the following steps:

  • Explanation of the research and the inclusion criteria.
  • Study/studies used.
  • Result of the systematic review/meta-analysis.
  • Sensitivity of the results.
  • Summarising in tables.

 

Various formats are used to report a systematic review/meta-analysis.

 

PRISMA 

(Option A)

Preferred Reporting Items - Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.

COCHRANE 

(Option B)

Based on a set of guidelines devised by the Cochrane organisation.

QUOROM 

(Option C)

Quality Of Reporting Of Meta-analysis (devised by the quorum group).

questions.text: Which of the following incorporates the advantage of researched science into a doctor’s clinical expertise and patient values?

choices.text: Correlational research
Controlled trials
Evidence-based medicine
Meta-analysis

questions.solution:
Evidence-based medicine incorporates well-researched and reliable scientific evidence into a doctor’s clinical expertise and patient values.

Steps for applying evidence-based medicine in practice:

 

The father of evidence-based medicine is David Sackett. The founder of evidence-based medicine is Gordon Guyatt.
